drawdown.translation[0].definitions[0].d: when a stock or supply of something is used
drawdown.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Strong demand for oil has resulted in a large drawdown in world stocks.
drawdown.translation[0].definitions[1].d: when someone obtains money as part of a loan that has already been agreed or uses money that they have saved
drawdown.translation[0].definitions[1].e: an income drawdown plan that allows you to keep your fund invested while drawing a regular income
drawdown.translation[0].definitions[2].d: a reduction in the value of an investment
drawdown.translation[0].definitions[2].e: Even if an investor says he is prepared for a 30% drawdown, he always finds it a worse experience then he imagined when it happens.
